moves.2... e6 3. e3 Nf6 4. Bd3 Nbd7 5. Nf3 c5: prematurely releasing pressure on the center allowing White to concentrate on his kingside attack
moves.9. Ne5 g6 10. h4 h5 11. Qf3 Nxe5 12. dxe: taking with the pawn is more common in the London in order to kick the knight, and it opens the d4 square for a future knight visit
moves.15... Bc5 16. Nf3 Be7 17. Nd4 Bd7 18. f3: the a1 rook is still sleeping and its absence on the kingside will soon be felt
moves.22. Rbg1 Qb6 23. Bg5: the q-side pawns are insignificant compared to the value of White's attack
to stop Ne6 leading to mate
moves.31. Rxh8 Rxe5 32. Rh7+: leading to forced mate after (Black resigned here)
